metadata.titleEn: GRFRV1.0: Global Reach-level 3-hourly river flood reanalysis (1980-2019)
metadata.description:
The global reach-level 3-hourly river flood reanalysis (GRFR) dataset includes 1) global 0.05 degree, 3-hourly/daily runoff data, 2) 3hourly/daily naturalized river discharge at 2.94 million river reaches, 3) global 3-hourly river flood events from 1980 to 2019, 4) underlying hydrography MERIT-Basins.
Grounded on recent breakthroughs in global runoff hydrology, river modeling, high-resolution hydrography, and climate reanalysis, the 3-hourly river discharge record globally for 2.94 million river reaches during the 40-yr period of 1980–2019 was developed. The underlying modeling chain consists of the VIC land surface model (0.05°, 3-hourly) that is well calibrated and bias-corrected and the RAPID routing model (2.94 million river and catchment vectors), with precipitation input from MSWEP and other meteorological fields downscaled from ERA5. Flood events (above 2-yr return) and their characteristics (number, spatial distribution, and seasonality) were extracted and studied. Validations against 3-hourly flow records from 6,000+ gauges in CONUS and daily records from 14,000+ gauges globally show good modeling performance across all flow ranges, good skills in reconstructing flood events (high extremes), and the benefit of (and need for) sub-daily modeling.
The GRFR database represents a pioneering effort on global reach-level flood reanalysis and may offer new opportunities for global flood studies in terms of baseline data and potential research pathways. Also, it can better help river-observing satellite missions to develop their discharge algorithms.
metadata.instructions:
The global VIC runoff is stored in nc format. The file name is "RUNOFF_yyyy. nc", where yyyy represents the year.
The river discharge is stored in nc format, and the file name is "output_pfaf_xx_1979-2019.nc", where xx represents the region, 01 represents Africa, 02 represents Europe, 03 represents North Asia (Siberia), 04 represents South Asia, 05 represents Oceania, 06 represents South America, 07 represents North America, and 08 represents the Arctic.
The global 3-hour river flood events data is stored in nc format. The file name is   "mswep_output_mswep_threshold_gt20_pfaf_xx_1980_2019_2daprt. nc", where xx represents the region.
The underlying hydrography dataset contains two levels. Level_01 provides the first level rivers (riv) and catchments (cat) infomation for pfaf 0x (where 0x stands for region). Level_02 provides the second level rivers (riv) and catchments (cat) information for pfaf xy, where x stands for region, y stands for the subregion y of the region x. The hydrography data are stored in shp and dbf format, which can be easily read by ARCGIS.

background: Floods are among the most frequent and costly natural disasters. According to a United Nations report (UNISDR 2015), floods accounted for 43% of occurrences of natural disasters during 1995–2015. The EM-DAT international disaster database indicates that fluvial floods contributed to two-thirds of flood events in the past two decades. Fluvial flood is the extreme upper tail of river hydrology that can happen at different scales. The lack of global long-term fine-scale (in both time and space) river discharge (Q) records has been the major hurdle for large-scale flood research. There are large gaps in river gauge data around the world as most gauges are concentrated in developed areas like North America and Europe. The other observational alternative is remote sensing, though the first satellite mission dedicated to discharge estimation will not launch until 2022. Continuous efforts have been made by the modeling community to quantify river discharge globally with increasingly finer spatial and temporal resolutions. Recent global studies with vector networks have illustrated their efficiency at high resolutions.
research objective: This study will inherit the basic modeling framework established in GRADES, make considerable efforts to upgrade the spatial and temporal resolutions from 0.25° daily to 0.05° 3-hourly, extend the temporal coverage (1980–2019), and carry out flood-specific (high extremes) analysis at subdaily time scales.
challenges: The lack of global long-term fine-scale (in both time and space) river discharge (Q) records has been the major hurdle for large-scale flood research. There are large gaps in river gauge data around the world as most gauges are concentrated in developed areas like North America and Europe. Model prediction errors are a combined result of model parameterization uncertainty and forcing (precipitation) errors, which are often hard to separate.
methods: We downscaled forcing fields to 0.05° using fine-scale elevation as the correction factor for temperature (fixed lapse rate of −6.5°C km−1), surface pressure (hydrostatic), longwave radiation (lapse adjustment for radiative temperature), humidity (lapse adjustment for saturated vapor pressure), wind speed (bilinear interpolation), and precipitation (bilinear interpolation). To reduce model biases, we performed grid-level parameter calibration and bias correction (postprocessing) against ML-derived, global runoff characteristic maps from the Global Streamflow Characteristics Dataset (GSCD). Instead of calibrating VIC against limited gauge observations, we calibrated three VIC parameters (infiltration curve shape, second soil layer thickness, and nonlinear baseflow threshold) at 0.25° grid pixel level, using the baseflow index, mean runoff, and runoff percentiles (Q10 and Q90) from the GSCD, and then resampled the parameters to 0.05° by bilinear interpolation. To reduce the remaining model biases after calibration, we applied the sparse cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching bias correction approach, which corrects the VIC runoff biases against nine runoff percentiles (Q1, Q5, Q10, Q20, Q50, Q80, Q90, Q95, and Q99) from the GSCD. The model was spun up for the 10-yr period of 1969–78 forced with downscaled Princeton Global Forcing (PGF) which has an original resolution of 0.25°. We implemented RAPID, a river routing model that uses a matrix-based version of the Muskingum method to calculate the flow and volume of water for each reach on a river network. Here, RAPID is run using a 30-min time step and forced with 3-hourly lateral inflows from VIC runoff.
dataset: Over CONUS, we compiled 3-hourly data over 9,000+ river gauges up to 2019 from the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS). After a similar screening, 6,000+ gauges match the river reaches being simulated and come with sufficient data for skill analysis. Validation of GRFR against 3-hourly flow records from 6,000+ gauges in CONUS and daily records from 14,000+ gauges globally shows good general skills of discharge estimates across all flow values, as well as good skills in reconstructing flood events (high extremes).
findings: Validation of GRFR against 3-hourly flow records from 6,000+ gauges in CONUS and daily records from 14,000+ gauges globally shows good general skills of discharge estimates across all flow values, as well as good skills in reconstructing flood events (high extremes). The effort to enable subdaily high-resolution modeling is expected to offer added values in capturing subdaily dynamics that may come with local and flashy events. The comparison between 3-hourly peaks and daily peaks highlights the significant benefit of (and need for) subdaily modeling for flood extremes. Precipitation sensitivity analysis suggests that, over well-gauged areas, the global product MSWEP performs very close to local product (Stage IV).

Verification.Question: Is it confirmed that the lack of global fine-scale river discharge records poses a challenge in large-scale flood research?
Does the data collection method include calibration of parameters specifically against global runoff characteristic maps instead of limited gauge observations?

Disjunctive.Question: Are the model biases in river discharge datasets more effectively reduced using grid-level parameter calibration, bias correction through CDF matching, or some other technique?

Concept Completion.Question: What are the common challenges faced in collecting global long-term fine-scale river discharge records?

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of sparse river gauge data in developing areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a data collection method that addresses the challenge of sparse river gauge data in developing areas is the use of remote sensing combined with a global hydrological model. The model utilizes downscaled forcing fields and grid-level parameter calibration to simulate river discharge with improved spatial and temporal resolution, as seen in the modeling approaches described for enhancing discharge estimation globally.

Example.Question: What is an example of a methodological approach to improve the accuracy of river discharge models?
Example.Answer: An example of a methodological approach to improve the accuracy of river discharge models is the use of bias correction techniques such as the sparse cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching approach. This method corrects biases in runoff predictions by adjusting model output against observed runoff percentiles from a global dataset, thereby enhancing the model's ability to reproduce both typical and extreme flood events.

Example.Question: Could you provide an example of a dataset that supports global flood research by offering fine-scale temporal and spatial data?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that supports global flood research by offering fine-scale temporal and spatial data is the 全球3小时河道洪水再分析数据GRFR V1.0, which includes global 0.05-degree, 3-hourly/diurnal land surface runoff data, simulated natural runoff data for 2.94 million river reaches, and flood event data. This dataset helps in capturing the dynamics of flood events across various regions, including data-scarce areas.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the distinguishing features of river discharge datasets that are derived from fine-scale spatial and temporal resolutions?
Feature Specification.Answer: 0.05° resolution, 3-hour intervals, high-resolution data, distributed hydrological models, river routing models, calibrated against global runoff characteristics, corrected for biases

Quantification.Question: How many river segments are included in the global dataset used for river simulation?
How many river gauges in the United States (CONUS) were used for skill analysis and validation of flow estimates?

Comparison.Question: How do the calibration and bias correction techniques used in the river discharge modeling compare to traditional river gauge methods in terms of accuracy and reliability?
Comparison.Answer: The calibration and bias correction techniques in the river discharge modeling involve grid-level parameter calibration and bias correction against global runoff characteristic maps, as well as a sparse cumulative distribution function (CDF) matching bias correction. These techniques aim to reduce model biases and improve accuracy, offering a robust alternative to traditional river gauge methods, which are limited by sparse global coverage and concentration in developed areas. The modeling approach has been shown to accurately reconstruct flood events and general discharge estimates.

Interpretation.Question: How does the use of fine-scale elevation as a correction factor in downscaling forcing fields influence the accuracy of river discharge simulations?
Interpretation.Answer: The use of fine-scale elevation as a correction factor helps in adjusting for temperature, surface pressure, and other meteorological parameters, thereby reducing errors in model predictions and improving the accuracy of river discharge simulations.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of model parameterization uncertainty and precipitation errors on the outcomes of river discharge modeling?
Interpretation.Answer: Model parameterization uncertainty and precipitation errors can significantly impact the accuracy of river discharge modeling, making it difficult to separate the two and necessitating robust calibration and bias correction methods to mitigate these issues.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for model calibration and bias correction in hydrological datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Model prediction errors can arise from uncertainties in model parameterization and forcing errors, such as precipitation. To address these issues, calibration against global runoff maps and bias correction methods, like sparse cumulative distribution function matching, are necessary to reduce biases and improve the accuracy of river discharge estimates.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using distributed hydrological models and river routing models for high-resolution global river discharge simulations?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The use of distributed hydrological models like VIC and river routing models such as RAPID can result in the capability to simulate global high-resolution natural river runoff systems with improved accuracy. These models allow for better replication of 3-hourly and daily river discharge processes and enhance the ability to capture flood events, which is particularly beneficial for regions lacking observational data.

Causal Consequence.Question: What effects might arise from the calibration and bias correction of hydrological models using global runoff characteristic maps?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Calibrating and applying bias correction to hydrological models using global runoff characteristic maps can significantly reduce model biases, improving the accuracy of discharge estimates. This process allows the models to better match observed runoff characteristics, enhancing their overall performance in simulating river discharge and reconstructing flood events, especially in regions with sparse observational data.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to enhance the spatial and temporal resolutions of river discharge data globally?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Enhancing the spatial and temporal resolutions of river discharge data globally is crucial because it enables more accurate and detailed flood-specific analysis at subdaily time scales. This improvement helps in capturing the dynamics of local and flashy flood events, which are not adequately represented in coarser datasets. Additionally, it addresses the significant gaps in river gauge data in less-developed areas, thereby facilitating better understanding and prediction of flood events across different regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: How do researchers aim to overcome the challenges associated with the lack of fine-scale river discharge records globally?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Researchers aim to overcome the challenges associated with the lack of fine-scale river discharge records globally by employing model parameter calibration and bias correction techniques. They downscale forcing fields using fine-scale elevation corrections, calibrate model parameters at grid levels using global runoff characteristics datasets, and apply bias correction approaches to adjust model outputs against observed data. These efforts are complemented by using a combination of hydrological and river routing models to simulate river discharges with improved accuracy and resolution.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can high-resolution spatial and temporal river discharge data be obtained and refined for global flood research?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: High-resolution spatial and temporal river discharge data can be obtained by downscaling forcing fields to a finer grid using elevation as a correction factor for various meteorological variables such as temperature, pressure, and precipitation. Additionally, a model calibration process is employed, where parameters are calibrated against global runoff characteristic maps and biases are corrected using a sparse CDF matching bias correction approach. A river routing model like RAPID is then used to simulate river flow using inflows from a hydrological model.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are utilized to address the challenge of data scarcity in river gauge observations for flood modeling?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To address data scarcity in river gauge observations, methodologies such as remote sensing, model calibration against global runoff data, and bias correction techniques are employed. The model parameters are calibrated using global datasets like the Global Streamflow Characteristics Dataset (GSCD), and biases are corrected against runoff percentiles from the same dataset. This approach reduces reliance on limited local gauge data and enhances model accuracy.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in validating a river discharge modeling system against observational data?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation of a river discharge modeling system involves compiling observational data from river gauges, conducting skill analysis by comparing model outputs with observed flow records, and assessing the model's ability to reconstruct flood events. For instance, validation can be carried out using 3-hourly flow records from thousands of river gauges in well-monitored areas like CONUS and daily records from global gauges, demonstrating the model's accuracy across various flow values and its efficacy in capturing flood extremes.

Enablement.Question: What data collection techniques enable the simulation of global high-resolution natural river runoff systems?
Enablement.Answer: The simulation of global high-resolution natural river runoff systems is enabled by a combination of distributed hydrological models like VIC and river routing models like RAPID, which use multi-source data and modeling techniques. This includes downscaling forcing fields to fine spatial resolutions and calibrating model parameters against global runoff characteristic maps, with further bias correction applied.

Enablement.Question: What role do technological advancements in remote sensing and modeling play in addressing the challenges of data scarcity in global flood research?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements in remote sensing and modeling help address data scarcity by offering alternative observational methods and enabling the development of global high-resolution datasets. These advancements support efforts to quantify river discharge with finer spatial and temporal resolutions, bridging gaps left by the uneven distribution of river gauge data, particularly in less developed regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be challenges in obtaining fine-scale river discharge records globally?
Expectation.Answer: The lack of global long-term fine-scale river discharge records is a major challenge due to large gaps in river gauge data, which are mostly concentrated in developed areas like North America and Europe. Remote sensing is an alternative, but the first satellite mission dedicated to discharge estimation will not launch until 2022.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected outcomes of implementing subdaily high-resolution modeling in flood research?
Expectation.Answer: Subdaily high-resolution modeling is expected to offer added values in capturing subdaily dynamics that may come with local and flashy flood events. It highlights the significant benefits and needs for subdaily modeling to accurately reconstruct flood events and provide better estimates of discharge across all flow values.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be difficulties in separating model prediction errors in large-scale flood research?
Expectation.Answer: Model prediction errors are often difficult to separate because they result from a combination of model parameterization uncertainty and forcing errors, such as those from precipitation data. The complexity in differentiating these factors contributes to the challenges in large-scale flood research.

Judgmental.Question: What are the main challenges faced in enhancing the accuracy of river discharge models, and how can they be addressed?
Judgmental.Answer: The main challenges in enhancing the accuracy of river discharge models include model parameterization uncertainty and forcing errors, which are difficult to separate. These challenges can be addressed by performing grid-level parameter calibration, bias correction, and using advanced downscaling techniques, as well as integrating more comprehensive observational data from sources like the Global Streamflow Characteristics Dataset.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways can the integration of remote sensing data improve the reliability of global flood analysis, especially in ungauged areas?
Judgmental.Answer: The integration of remote sensing data can significantly improve the reliability of global flood analysis by providing additional observational data in ungauged areas. Although the first dedicated discharge estimation satellite mission is not yet launched, remote sensing can offer alternative data sources that complement existing ground-based measurements, enhancing spatial and temporal resolution and helping capture flood dynamics.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about how challenges in data collection are addressed when there are large gaps in river gauge data worldwide.
Assertion.Answer: Challenges in data collection due to large gaps in river gauge data are addressed by using remote sensing and modeling techniques to estimate river discharge. Calibration against global datasets and using models like VIC and RAPID with a matrix-based Muskingum method help in creating accurate simulations even in ungauged regions.

Assertion.Question: I can't make sense of how data validation is effectively conducted for datasets with such a vast temporal and spatial coverage.
Assertion.Answer: Data validation for datasets with vast temporal and spatial coverage is conducted by comparing model outputs with observed data from thousands of river gauges across the globe. The process involves ensuring that the model can accurately reconstruct flow values and flood events, with specific validation against 3-hourly and daily records.
